Issues.Title: ci: upgrade clang-format to 1.0.27 to match master
Issues.Body: We need to update the patch branch to the same version of clang-format as master. Otherwise changes cherry-picked to both master and patch may fail on patch because the linter standards are different.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "ci: upgrade clang-format to 1.0.27 to match master" (#31247)

Issues.Title: ci(docs-infra): re-enable payload size checking for `test_aio_local` and `test_aio_local_ivy`
Issues.Body:
Previously, payload size checking for `test_aio_local` and `test_aio_local_ivy` was disabled on the 8.0.x branch (in #31064), because the numbers (which were cherry-picked from master) did not match the actual sizes.

This commit updates the numbers for the 8.0.x branch and re-enables the checks.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "ci(docs-infra): re-enable payload size checking for `test_aio_local` and `test_aio_local_ivy`" (#31243)

Issues.Title: fix(bazel): update ng new schema to match the current ng new schema o‚Ä¶
Issues.Body:
**fix(bazel): update ng new schema to match the current ng new schema of @schematics/angular**
The schema used in ng-new bazel, includes several outdated options. With this update we match the current version of @schematics/angular: https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/master/packages/schematics/angular/ng-new/schema.json

Relates to #31233

**fix(bazel): remove unsupported Css pre-processors from ng new** 
 Under Bazel, we don't yet support Stylus and Less, and thus we should not offer the users to generate applications which are known not to work.

Closes #31209
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(bazel): update ng new schema to match the current ng new schema o‚Ä¶" (#31234)

Issues.Title: fix(ivy): incorrect namespace for root node created through ViewContainerRef
Issues.Body:
Currently in Ivy whenever we encounter a new namespace, we set it in the global state so that all subsequent nodes are created under the same namespace. Next time a template is run the namespace will be reset back to HTML.

This breaks down if the last node that was rendered was under the SVG or MathML namespace and we create a component through `ViewContainerRef.create`, because the next template function hasn't run yet and it hasn't had the chance to update the namespace. The result is that the root node of the new component will retain the wrong namespace and may not end up rendering at all (e.g. if we're trying to show a `div` inside the SVG namespace). This issue has the potential to affect a lot of apps, because all components inserted through the router also go through `ViewContainerRef.create`.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(ivy): incorrect namespace for root node created through ViewContainerRef" (#31232)

Issues.Title: Uninformative Documentation
Issues.Body:
**Webpage**: [HostListener](https://angular.io/api/core/HostListener)

**Issue**
I'd consider myself barely an adept at Angular, but it wasn't too long ago since I was a complete novice. I found that certain areas of the Angular documentation are very uninformative (_perhaps I am not reading them correctly?_). 

For example the HostListener section of the documentation does not cover what type of events are covered or how to call them. I personally found the explanation of the method a bit brief. I have found in other sections as well that it is often assumes that the reader has a certain level of understanding of Angular instead of endeavouring to be as informative and in depth as possible. This has led to lengthy discussions online and searches outside of the [Angular](https://angular.io/) website as well beginners lacking an understanding of the possibilities and scope for the method's application.

I would appreciate that (and I am sure so would many other developers) cited complex as well as simple examples of the method's application would be given. Thank you.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Uninformative Documentation" (#31225)

Issues.Title: question: why doesn't Javascript have optional static typing ?
Issues.Body:
tc39 is adding new things to JS. But why not optional static typing ?

If they do it, we don't have to use Typescript anymore and being able to pass type information to the engine.

We will have less dev dependency.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "question: why doesn't Javascript have optional static typing ?" (#31219)

Issues.Title: aot compiler silently misbehaves with expressions derived from es6 default exports
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Affected Package Not sure - angular's compiler is black magic to me as of now ;). ### Is this a regression? Not sure. ### Description First off, I thought it's related to https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/11402 but it doesn't look like it - in that case it at least gives you an error and dies, but in this case it compiles with wrong results. So I think this is a separate issue. On to the description... Assuming you have environment.ANIMATIONS set to false, one would expect the following two to both useValue false... ```typescript @NgModule({ providers: [ { provide: 'shouldBeFalse', useValue: environment.ANIMATIONS === true ? true : false }, environment.ANIMATIONS === true ? { provide: 'shouldAlsoBeFalse', useValue: true } : { provide: 'shouldAlsoBeFalse', useValue: false }, ], }) ``` ...but they don't. For some reason, the first case behaves as expected, but the second does NOT, at least in my test case I'll link below. I think it'll be easier to just look at the diff, but the specific details to make it misbehave (and silently!) are as follows: - AoT - environment is a const that comes from a named export in another file - environment.ANIMATIONS is an expression that depends on an object that comes from a default export of yet another file. After a couple days of experimentation to figure out why false is true, I was able to get the second pattern to work by changing the second export from a default export to a named export. I've had the compiler yell at me before when something isn't statically analyzable, but sadly in this case it just merrily gives the wrong result. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction StackBlitz for some reason can't reproduce the problem, and I think it's because it's running JIT. But here's a PR diff showing how to reproduce it: https://github.com/captaincaius/rocketdefaultexporttestcase/pull/1/files#diff-5c26d2c8f8838f32ace87fdecd6344eaL26 ## üî• Exception or Error

Issues.Title: NullInjectorError when running with --prod
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) ``` - [ ] new - [x] build - [x] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ``` ### Is this a regression? Yes this is a regression in `@angular-devkit/build-angular` starting from `0.800.2` (works with `0.800.1`). ### Description After building or serving with `--prod` (probably the build optimizer when I look at changes between `0.800.1` and `0.800.2`) I get a `NullInjectorError` ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction DI setup: - App module - Core module -> NGXS/States - NGXS bootstraps/initializes the states - `AuthState` -> (`Store`, `AuthApiService`, `LoggerService`) The one not found is the `AuthApiService`. I am aware that this might as well be an issue with NGXS and that this is not really a viable way for you guys to reproduce the issue. But given the very few commits between 0.800.1 and 0.800.2 I though you might be able to still pin down the issue or give me more information on why this issue occurs now. If not, I might be able to dig deeper and/or figure out if it's an NGXS issue and/or reproduce it minimally. However, it is a regression. ## üî• Exception or Error 

core.js.pre-build-optimizer.js:1354 Uncaught NullInjectorError: StaticInjectorError(s)[r -> a]: 
  StaticInjectorError(Platform: core)[r -> a]: 
    NullInjectorError: No provider for a!

Issues.Title: fix(@angular/cli): validate version in doc command
Issues.Body:
As the JSON Schema validation is minimum in the CLI, we have to also validate in code.
This PR:
- updates the JSON Schema to use `number` and `enum` instead of `integer` and `const` that are not supported.
- adds validation in the doc command implementation
- adds error reporting if the version is not valid
- fixes a typo in an error message in the parser
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(@angular/cli): validate version in doc command" (#14858)

Issues.Title: Error when using exported interface
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) ``` - [ ] new - [ ] build - [x] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ``` ### Is this a regression? Yes, the previous version in which this bug was not present was: 8.0.3 (See "anything else relevant" section, exact bug has appeared and been fixed before) ### Description A clear and concise description of the problem... Using an exported interface produces an error, app is not served. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction export an interface: ``` export interface AppConfig {..} export let APP_CONFIG = new InjectionToken('app.config'); ``` Import it elsewhere: `import { APP_CONFIG, AppConfig } from '../app.config';` Use it: ``` export class MyService { constructor(@Inject(APP_CONFIG) config: AppConfig,... ... } ``` ## üî• Exception or Error ng serve 
ERROR in ./src/app/shared/my.service.ts 20:12-21

App is not served. Havent tried build. ## üåç Your Environment

```
- [ ] update
- [ ] lint
- [ ] xi18n
- [ ] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc
```

### Description
There are lots of ~~Enterprise~~ Angular Apps that have really spotty testing. There isn't a way to generate a .spec.ts file for an existing component or service. Wiring up a TestingModule for each component is a slow process by hand if you are not familiar with the code base.


### Describe the solution you'd like
The ability to generate a spec file similar to that which `ng generate component` generates but from an existing component or service.

`ng generate spec app.component.ts`


### Describe alternatives you've considered
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Generate Spec File For Existing Component/Service" (#14872)

Issues.Title: ng build should --prod by default
Issues.Body:
<!--üîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖ

Oh hi there! üòÑ

To expedite issue processing please search open and closed issues before submitting a new one.
Existing issues often contain information about workarounds, resolution, or progress updates.

üîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖ-->


# üöÄ Feature request


### Command (mark with an `x`)
<!-- Can you pin-point the command or commands that are relevant for this feature request? -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit: -->
```
- [ ] new
- [x] build
- [ ] serve
- [ ] test
- [ ] e2e
- [ ] generate
- [ ] add
- [ ] update
- [ ] lint
- [ ] xi18n
- [ ] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc
```

### Description

We maintain an angular component library and we almost could receive dozens of the same question every week, that is 
> `Why the angular build out is so big(3MB or larger)? and why the performance is so poor? we do not want to use it any longer`

when they run `ng build` or `npm run build`

We have to explain that `prod` mode is not the default mode, plz use `ng build --prod` instead.

The `ng build --prod` has been detailed in the official documentation, but many new users just skip the document and just run `npm run build (equals ng build)` in the project generated by `@angular/cli`.

Angular may lose quite a lot of users due to the misunderstanding of `ng build`.
I think it is time to make `--prod` mode default in command `ng build`.


### Describe the solution you'd like
make `--prod` mode default in command `ng build`.

### Describe alternatives you've considered

it may bring break changes, but I think most of the angular developers should use `ng build --prod` now
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "ng build should --prod by default" (#14870)

Issues.Title: Angular library asset images are not accessible in consumer app production build.
Issues.Body:
I have an angular library named common-sec in which created assets folder manually under the lib folder. I used images from the assets folder in my library component. named "login".

I have used login component from common-sec library in my main angular app.

By running main app with ng serve, library images of assets folder loading perfectly. But when i build my main app using ng build --prod --base-href /prefix/, none of library images rendedred.

I see it tries to request images at localhost:4200/assets/image.png (return 404)
But i see images are available at ocalhost:4200/prefix/assets/image.png

Is it a bug or it's known issue in angular-cli?

Issues.Title: fix(@angular-devkit/build-angular): polyfill URL to support $location
Issues.Body:
The `$location` service relies on the URL constructor which is not present in IE9-11.  core-js provides a polyfill which has now been added to the ES5 polyfill set which will be loaded for IE9-11.

Size check failure is expected due to the addition of ES5 polyfills.
Gzipped size change is 38kb -> 44kb
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(@angular-devkit/build-angular): polyfill URL to support $location" (#14847)

Issues.Title: mat-tab-group ignores parent width when inside fxLayout row
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

[Stackblitz](https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-qube6g)

Steps to reproduce:
1. Add `mat-tab-group` inside div container having `fxFlexLayout="row"`
2. Add more `mat-tab` elements than the parent container width can display
 
 
#### Expected Behavior

The tab header should provide the usual left and right arrow indicating that there are more tabs than the current view shows (as it does if inside a fxLayout="column")

#### Actual Behavior

The tab-group grows in width and actually renders alls tabs even if there is no space. There are no arrows.

#### Environment

- Angular: ^8.0.0
- CDK/Material: ^8.0.1
- Browser(s): Chrome 75.0.3770.100
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): macOS
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "mat-tab-group ignores parent width when inside fxLayout row" (#16371)

Issues.Title: cdkDragFreeDragPosition
Issues.Body:
#### Feature Description

Provide a brief summary of the feature you would like to see.

cdkDragFreeDragPosition should accept x,y in relative units such as vw & vh

#### Use Case

Describe the use case(s) that the proposed feature would enable.

cdkDragFreeDragPosition allows to persist & restore drag position - however it takes only numeric values as px. This affects the responsive webpages and controls do not show up as expected because the transform:translate is set as px values. Currently, it has to be handled manually while loading pages to change the dragposition values based on screen width/height
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "cdkDragFreeDragPosition " (#16364)

Issues.Title: build: use bazel from node modules
Issues.Body:
The goal of https://github.com/angular/components/commit/2ce5ffd56b70c3791331ceedeadc1f1f6daf3924 was to avoid the use of Bazel through the `node_modules`
because it adds unnecessary code overhead, slows down CI and means that
some tools need to be installed multiple times (such as `yarn`). Unfortunately
when building a release with Bazel right now, the bazel workspace status script
depends on the global `node` binary. This means that we need to bring in Node
when running with the `--config=release` flag.. Since that causes inconsistent behavior
and just complicates the setup, we are using Bazel through Yarn for now. Similar to how
we did it for `angular/angular` with https://github.com/angular/angular/commit/8fc4ae51fb66d14f6dc82712a536c3842205fc6d.

We need to revisit this overall approach in the future.. but for now this seems to be the
simplest approach and we don't want too much effort into this yet. Seems like a general
question for #dev-infra where we need to figure out the ideal approach.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "build: use bazel from node modules" (#16361)

Issues.Title: virtual-scroll: mat-select with virtual scroll loses selection state
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-2rtvdn

This stackblitz demos 2 mat-selects. 

The one on the left is a standard mat-select. This one works fine on every situation (despite the performace issues that may arise when using large dataproviders)

The one on the right is a mat-select using virtual-scroll. This one has several issues. I will just describe one here which I believe it's not been filed yet.

Steps to reproduce:

1. Select an option from the mat-select on the Right. The option is displayed fine once the selector gets closed.

2. Now open again the mat-select on the right. The selector shows nothing (#15902) but we let's continue working.

3. With the "blank" selector opened, scroll down using the mouse wheel. You will see options are displayed again. Scroll to some position where the "selected" value is not longer visible (outside the MatOption instances used by the virtual scroll). Now Press "ESC". 

4. Boom! The selector goes away (expected) but, despite the mat-select has a "value" set, the component shows nothing.
 
 
#### Expected Behavior

If we hit "ESC" o "click outside the mat-select", the control should always display the selected value, no matter if it's using default or virtual scroll.


#### Actual Behavior

The selected option is no longer displayed (but it's still set).

Obs:

1) "mat-select" seems to re-calculate its internal "selectionModel" and "empty" states once the selector is closed. It calculates this state using the available MatOptions which, of course, are not the full-set of options when using virtual scroll.

2) I don't know if this is a "virtual-scroll" bug or a "mat-select" bug but, anyway, the combination of both is crashing (somehow).

#### Environment

- Angular: 8.0.1
- CDK/Material: 8.0.1
- Browser(s): Chrome 74
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows 10
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "virtual-scroll: mat-select with virtual scroll loses selection state" (#16352)

Issues.Title: Import Scrollmodule instead of deprecated ScrollDispatchModule
Issues.Body:
#### Documentation Feedback

The Scrolling CDK documentation has the following snippet to use the scrolling module:

```ts
import {ScrollDispatchModule} from '@angular/cdk/scrolling';
```

However, it was deprecated, and `ScrollModule` should be imported instead.

![Screenshot 2019-06-21 09 48 49](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10211603/59931092-d9ba6a00-9409-11e9-8560-7d2963ffa511.png)

**Affected documentation page:** https://material.angular.io/cdk/scrolling/api
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Import Scrollmodule instead of deprecated ScrollDispatchModule" (#16353)

Issues.Title: fix(bottom-sheet): DOM nodes not cleaned up if view container is destroyed mid-animation
Issues.Body:
Along the same lines as #16309.

Currently the bottom sheet's cleanup logic is tied to its exit animation completing. This usually isn't a problem since by default the bottom sheet is attached to the application ref, however if the consumer has set a viewContainerRef and that ref is destroyed mid-animation, the exit animation event will never fire. These changes add a timeout as a fallback in case the animation doesn't finish in the specified time.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(bottom-sheet): DOM nodes not cleaned up if view container is destroyed mid-animation" (#16349)
